Nor shrieking owls were heard, nor crowing cocks,</br>But sleep and silence held their peaceful reign;</br>No foot that stirr'd, save of the prowling fox,</br>Or hare that crop'd the verdure of the plain:
The plain, where, on a gibbet high in air</br>The Murd'rer hangs; and veers with every wind,</br>The gaze of reckless fools, the maiden's fear,</br>But moral lesson to the thoughtful mind.
At that drear time of night the flitting Ghost</br>That once had dwelt within those foul remains,</br>Hov'ring around, now view'd the fatal spot,</br>Now mark'd with anguish the impris'ning chains.
Oh, dire effect of passion and excess!</br>Such are, she cries, the triumphs you obtain,</br>These iron wreaths, O guilt, thy temples press,</br>And this the pile thou rear'st with so much pain.
Ah, much-lov'd carcass once!  now doom'd to bear</br>The North hard-driving, and the biting East;</br>Thy guardian I!  corruption learn to spare,</br>Flee hungry ravens the forbidden feast.
But why thy far less dreadful lot deplore?</br>Ye hungry ravens, make your putrid meal;</br>Past thy last fatal struggle, thou no more</br>Nor driving North, nor biting East canst feel.
Those feet that once my active impulse own'd,</br>That impious hand, whose aim, alas!  too just</br>Obey'd my rage (Oh, be that rage aton'd)</br>Depriv'd of sense, shall moulder into dust.
Vain is the hope of sinking into nought,</br>Thy envied privilege to me deny'd;</br>Oh!  could I taste like thee Oblivion's draught,</br>To hush my fears, and lay my griefs aside.
Driven with winds, or drench'd in misty air,</br>I, like a wounded stag, no rest can find;</br>Guilt's arrows deep infix'd about me bear,</br>Whilst angry Justice presses hard behind.

Yet, impious wretch, that dar'st to bound what knows</br>No bounds — the tender mercies of thy God;</br>Kiss the inflicted, that in soft repose</br>Ev'n thou, perhaps, may'st bless th' averted rod.</br>
